segment.source: After obtaining information about the devices that are currently part of the IT infrastructure, you must determine at what point a device is considered trusted.
segment.target: After obtaining information about the devices that are currently part of the IT infrastructure, you must determine at what point a device is considered trusted.

segment.source: The term trusted can mean different things to different people.
segment.target: The term trusted can mean different things to different people.

segment.source: Therefore, you must communicate a firm definition for it to all stakeholders in the project.
segment.target: Therefore, you must communicate a firm definition for it to all stakeholders in the project.

segment.source: Failure to do this can lead to problems with the security of the trusted environment, because the overall security cannot exceed the level of security set by the least secure client that achieves trusted status.
segment.target: Failure to do this can lead to problems with the security of the trusted environment, because the overall security cannot exceed the level of security set by the least secure client that achieves trusted status.

segment.source: Note: In this context, the term trust has nothing to do with an Active Directory trust relationship between domains.
segment.target: Note: In this context, the term trust has nothing to do with an Active Directory trust relationship between domains.

segment.source: The trusted state of your devices just indicates the level of risk that you believe the device brings to the network.
segment.target: The trusted state of your devices just indicates the level of risk that you believe the device brings to the network.

segment.source: Trusted devices bring little risk whereas untrusted devices can potentially bring great risk.
segment.target: Trusted devices bring little risk whereas untrusted devices can potentially bring great risk.

segment.source: Trust states
segment.target: Trust states

segment.source: To understand this concept, consider the four basic states that apply to devices in a typical IT infrastructure.
segment.target: To understand this concept, consider the four basic states that apply to devices in a typical IT infrastructure.

segment.source: These states are (in order of risk, lowest risk first):
segment.target: These states are (in order of risk, lowest risk first):

segment.source: Trusted
segment.target: Trusted

segment.source: Trustworthy
segment.target: Trustworthy

segment.source: Known, untrusted
segment.target: Known, untrusted

segment.source: Unknown, untrusted
segment.target: Unknown, untrusted

segment.source: The remainder of this section defines these states and how to determine which devices in your organization belong in each state.
segment.target: The remainder of this section defines these states and how to determine which devices in your organization belong in each state.

segment.source: Trusted state
segment.target: Trusted state

segment.source: Classifying a device as trusted means that the device's security risks are managed, but it does not imply that it is perfectly secure or invulnerable.
segment.target: Classifying a device as trusted means that the device's security risks are managed, but it does not imply that it is perfectly secure or invulnerable.

segment.source: The responsibility for this managed state falls to the IT and security administrators, in addition to the users who are responsible for the configuration of the device.
segment.target: The responsibility for this managed state falls to the IT and security administrators, in addition to the users who are responsible for the configuration of the device.

segment.source: A trusted device that is poorly managed will likely become a point of weakness for the network.
segment.target: A trusted device that is poorly managed will likely become a point of weakness for the network.

segment.source: When a device is considered trusted, other trusted devices can reasonably assume that the device will not initiate a malicious act.
segment.target: When a device is considered trusted, other trusted devices can reasonably assume that the device will not initiate a malicious act.

segment.source: For example, trusted devices can expect that other trusted devices will not run a virus that attacks them, because all trusted devices are required to use mechanisms (such as antivirus software) to mitigate the threat of viruses.
segment.target: For example, trusted devices can expect that other trusted devices will not run a virus that attacks them, because all trusted devices are required to use mechanisms (such as antivirus software) to mitigate the threat of viruses.

segment.source: Spend some time defining the goals and technology requirements that your organization considers appropriate as the minimum configuration for a device to obtain trusted status.
segment.target: Spend some time defining the goals and technology requirements that your organization considers appropriate as the minimum configuration for a device to obtain trusted status.

segment.source: A possible list of technology requirements might include the following:
segment.target: A possible list of technology requirements might include the following:

segment.source: Operating system.
segment.target: Operating system.

segment.source: A trusted client device should run at least Windows Vista.
segment.target: A trusted client device should run at least Windows Vista.

segment.source: A trusted server should run at least Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: A trusted server should run at least Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: Domain membership.
segment.target: Domain membership.

segment.source: A trusted device will belong to a managed Active Directory domain, which means that the IT department has security management rights and can configure member devices by using Group Policy.
segment.target: A trusted device will belong to a managed Active Directory domain, which means that the IT department has security management rights and can configure member devices by using Group Policy.

segment.source: Management client.
segment.target: Management client.

segment.source: All trusted devices must run a specific network management client to allow for centralized management and control of security policies, configurations, and software.
segment.target: All trusted devices must run a specific network management client to allow for centralized management and control of security policies, configurations, and software.

segment.source: Configuration Manager is one such management system with an appropriate client.
segment.target: Configuration Manager is one such management system with an appropriate client.

segment.source: Antivirus software.
segment.target: Antivirus software.

segment.source: All trusted devices will run antivirus software that is configured to check for and automatically update the latest virus signature files daily.
segment.target: All trusted devices will run antivirus software that is configured to check for and automatically update the latest virus signature files daily.

segment.source: File system.
segment.target: File system.

segment.source: All trusted devices will be configured to use the NTFS file system.
segment.target: All trusted devices will be configured to use the NTFS file system.

segment.source: BIOS settings.
segment.target: BIOS settings.

segment.source: All trusted portable devices will be configured to use a BIOS-level password that is under the management of the IT support team.
segment.target: All trusted portable devices will be configured to use a BIOS-level password that is under the management of the IT support team.

segment.source: Password requirements.
segment.target: Password requirements.

segment.source: Trusted clients must use strong passwords.
segment.target: Trusted clients must use strong passwords.

segment.source: It is important to understand that the trusted state is not constant; it is a transient state that is subject to changing security standards and compliance with those standards.
segment.target: It is important to understand that the trusted state is not constant; it is a transient state that is subject to changing security standards and compliance with those standards.

segment.source: New threats and new defenses emerge constantly.
segment.target: New threats and new defenses emerge constantly.

segment.source: For this reason, the organization's management systems must continually check the trusted devices to ensure ongoing compliance.
segment.target: For this reason, the organization's management systems must continually check the trusted devices to ensure ongoing compliance.

segment.source: Additionally, the management systems must be able to issue updates or configuration changes if they are required to help maintain the trusted status.
segment.target: Additionally, the management systems must be able to issue updates or configuration changes if they are required to help maintain the trusted status.

segment.source: A device that continues to meet all these security requirements can be considered trusted.
segment.target: A device that continues to meet all these security requirements can be considered trusted.

segment.source: However it is possible that most devices that were identified in the discovery process discussed earlier do not meet these requirements.
segment.target: However it is possible that most devices that were identified in the discovery process discussed earlier do not meet these requirements.

segment.source: Therefore, you must identify which devices can be trusted and which ones cannot.
segment.target: Therefore, you must identify which devices can be trusted and which ones cannot.

segment.source: To help with this process, you use the intermediate trustworthy state.
segment.target: To help with this process, you use the intermediate trustworthy state.

segment.source: The remainder of this section discusses the different states and their implications.
segment.target: The remainder of this section discusses the different states and their implications.

segment.source: Trustworthy state
segment.target: Trustworthy state

segment.source: It is useful to identify as soon as possible those devices in your current infrastructure that can achieve a trusted state.
segment.target: It is useful to identify as soon as possible those devices in your current infrastructure that can achieve a trusted state.

segment.source: A trustworthy state can be assigned to indicate that the current device can physically achieve the trusted state with required software and configuration changes.
segment.target: A trustworthy state can be assigned to indicate that the current device can physically achieve the trusted state with required software and configuration changes.

segment.source: For each device that is assigned a trustworthy status, make an accompanying configuration note that states what is required to enable the device to achieve trusted status.
segment.target: For each device that is assigned a trustworthy status, make an accompanying configuration note that states what is required to enable the device to achieve trusted status.

segment.source: This information is especially important to both the project design team (to estimate the costs of adding the device to the solution) and the support staff (to enable them to apply the required configuration).
segment.target: This information is especially important to both the project design team (to estimate the costs of adding the device to the solution) and the support staff (to enable them to apply the required configuration).

segment.source: Generally, trustworthy devices fall into one of the following two groups:
segment.target: Generally, trustworthy devices fall into one of the following two groups:

segment.source: Configuration required.
segment.target: Configuration required.

segment.source: The current hardware, operating system, and software enable the device to achieve a trustworthy state.
segment.target: The current hardware, operating system, and software enable the device to achieve a trustworthy state.

segment.source: However, additional configuration changes are required.
segment.target: However, additional configuration changes are required.

segment.source: For example, if the organization requires a secure file system before a device can be considered trusted, a device that uses a FAT32-formatted hard disk does not meet this requirement.
segment.target: For example, if the organization requires a secure file system before a device can be considered trusted, a device that uses a FAT32-formatted hard disk does not meet this requirement.

segment.source: Upgrade required.
segment.target: Upgrade required.

segment.source: These devices require upgrades before they can be considered trusted.
segment.target: These devices require upgrades before they can be considered trusted.

segment.source: The following list provides some examples of the type of upgrade these devices might require:
segment.target: The following list provides some examples of the type of upgrade these devices might require:

segment.source: Operating system upgrade required.
segment.target: Operating system upgrade required.

segment.source: If the device's current operating system cannot support the security needs of the organization, an upgrade would be required before the device could achieve a trusted state.
segment.target: If the device's current operating system cannot support the security needs of the organization, an upgrade would be required before the device could achieve a trusted state.

segment.source: Software required.
segment.target: Software required.

segment.source: A device that is missing a required security application, such as an antivirus scanner or a management client, cannot be considered trusted until these applications are installed and active.
segment.target: A device that is missing a required security application, such as an antivirus scanner or a management client, cannot be considered trusted until these applications are installed and active.

segment.source: Hardware upgrade required.
segment.target: Hardware upgrade required.

segment.source: In some cases, a device might require a specific hardware upgrade before it can achieve trusted status.
segment.target: In some cases, a device might require a specific hardware upgrade before it can achieve trusted status.

segment.source: This type of device usually needs an operating system upgrade or additional software that forces the required hardware upgrade.
segment.target: This type of device usually needs an operating system upgrade or additional software that forces the required hardware upgrade.

segment.source: For example, security software might require additional hard disk space on the device.
segment.target: For example, security software might require additional hard disk space on the device.

segment.source: Device replacement required.
segment.target: Device replacement required.

segment.source: This category is reserved for devices that cannot support the security requirements of the solution because their hardware cannot support the minimum acceptable configuration.
segment.target: This category is reserved for devices that cannot support the security requirements of the solution because their hardware cannot support the minimum acceptable configuration.

segment.source: For example, a device that cannot run a secure operating system because it has an old processor (such as a 100-megahertz MHz x86-based device).
segment.target: For example, a device that cannot run a secure operating system because it has an old processor (such as a 100-megahertz MHz x86-based device).

segment.source: Use these groups to assign costs for implementing the solution on the devices that require upgrades.
segment.target: Use these groups to assign costs for implementing the solution on the devices that require upgrades.

segment.source: Known, untrusted state
segment.target: Known, untrusted state

segment.source: During the process of categorizing an organization's devices, you will identify some devices that cannot achieve trusted status for specific well-understood and well-defined reasons.
segment.target: During the process of categorizing an organization's devices, you will identify some devices that cannot achieve trusted status for specific well-understood and well-defined reasons.

segment.source: These reasons might include the following types:
segment.target: These reasons might include the following types:

segment.source: Financial.
segment.target: Financial.

segment.source: The funding is not available to upgrade the hardware or software for this device.
segment.target: The funding is not available to upgrade the hardware or software for this device.

segment.source: Political.
segment.target: Political.

segment.source: The device must remain in an untrusted state because of a political or business situation that does not enable it to comply with the stated minimum security requirements of the organization.
segment.target: The device must remain in an untrusted state because of a political or business situation that does not enable it to comply with the stated minimum security requirements of the organization.

segment.source: It is highly recommended that you contact the business owner or independent software vendor (ISV) for the device to discuss the added value of server and domain isolation.
segment.target: It is highly recommended that you contact the business owner or independent software vendor (ISV) for the device to discuss the added value of server and domain isolation.

segment.source: Functional.
segment.target: Functional.

segment.source: The device must run a nonsecure operating system or must operate in a nonsecure manner to perform its role.
segment.target: The device must run a nonsecure operating system or must operate in a nonsecure manner to perform its role.

segment.source: For example, the device might be required to run an older operating system because a specific line of business application will only work on that operating system.
segment.target: For example, the device might be required to run an older operating system because a specific line of business application will only work on that operating system.

segment.source: There can be multiple functional reasons for a device to remain in the known untrusted state.
segment.target: There can be multiple functional reasons for a device to remain in the known untrusted state.

segment.source: The following list includes several examples of functional reasons that can lead to a classification of this state:
segment.target: The following list includes several examples of functional reasons that can lead to a classification of this state:

segment.source: Devices that run unsupported versions of Windows.
segment.target: Devices that run unsupported versions of Windows.

segment.source: This includes Windows XP, Windows Millennium Edition, Windows 98, Windows 95, or Windows NT.
segment.target: This includes Windows XP, Windows Millennium Edition, Windows 98, Windows 95, or Windows NT.

segment.source: Devices that run these versions of the Windows operating system cannot be classified as trustworthy because these operating systems do not support the required security infrastructure.
segment.target: Devices that run these versions of the Windows operating system cannot be classified as trustworthy because these operating systems do not support the required security infrastructure.

segment.source: For example, although Windows NT does support a basic security infrastructure, it does not support “deny” ACLs on local resources, any way to ensure the confidentiality and integrity of network communications, smart cards for strong authentication, or centralized management of device configurations (although limited central management of user configurations is supported).
segment.target: For example, although Windows NT does support a basic security infrastructure, it does not support “deny” ACLs on local resources, any way to ensure the confidentiality and integrity of network communications, smart cards for strong authentication, or centralized management of device configurations (although limited central management of user configurations is supported).

segment.source: Stand-alone devices.
segment.target: Stand-alone devices.

segment.source: Devices running any version of Windows that are configured as stand-alone devices or as members of a workgroup usually cannot achieve a trustworthy state.
segment.target: Devices running any version of Windows that are configured as stand-alone devices or as members of a workgroup usually cannot achieve a trustworthy state.

segment.source: Although these devices fully support the minimum required basic security infrastructure, the required security management capabilities are unlikely to be available when the device is not a part of a trusted domain.
segment.target: Although these devices fully support the minimum required basic security infrastructure, the required security management capabilities are unlikely to be available when the device is not a part of a trusted domain.

segment.source: Devices in an untrusted domain.
segment.target: Devices in an untrusted domain.

segment.source: A device that is a member of a domain that is not trusted by an organization's IT department cannot be classified as trusted.
segment.target: A device that is a member of a domain that is not trusted by an organization's IT department cannot be classified as trusted.

segment.source: An untrusted domain is a domain that cannot provide the required security capabilities to its members.
segment.target: An untrusted domain is a domain that cannot provide the required security capabilities to its members.

segment.source: Although the operating systems of devices that are members of this untrusted domain might fully support the minimum required basic security infrastructure, the required security management capabilities cannot be fully guaranteed when devices are not in a trusted domain.
segment.target: Although the operating systems of devices that are members of this untrusted domain might fully support the minimum required basic security infrastructure, the required security management capabilities cannot be fully guaranteed when devices are not in a trusted domain.

segment.source: Unknown, untrusted state
segment.target: Unknown, untrusted state

segment.source: The unknown, untrusted state should be considered the default state for all devices.
segment.target: The unknown, untrusted state should be considered the default state for all devices.

segment.source: Because devices in this state have a configuration that is unknown, you can assign no trust to them.
segment.target: Because devices in this state have a configuration that is unknown, you can assign no trust to them.

segment.source: All planning for devices in this state must assume that the device is an unacceptable risk to the organization.
segment.target: All planning for devices in this state must assume that the device is an unacceptable risk to the organization.

segment.source: Designers of the solution should strive to minimize the impact that the devices in this state can have on their organizations.
segment.target: Designers of the solution should strive to minimize the impact that the devices in this state can have on their organizations.
